repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Health System Modernization
            Project and Social Sector Reform Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health System
            Modernization Project (HSMP) for Albania were as follows:
            outcome was moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was significant, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Ratings for the Social Sector Reform
            Development Policy Loan (DPL) Project for Albania were as
            follows: outcome was moderately satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            high quality of the Bank's analytic work and technical
            assistance is necessary but not sufficient for
            effectiveness. Also important are the involvement and buy-in
            of the government and other key stakeholders and the
            strategic packaging of support with other Bank products and
            services. One-tranche DPLs can be transformative and support
            reform momentum if: (i) build on solid analytic work; (ii)
            can effectively leverage critical policy change (for
            example, legislation) that may not gain sufficient traction
            through sector dialogue alone; and (iii) supported by
            continuity in the sector policy dialogue and lending after
            the DPL closes. Political economy is critical to factor into
            reform design and risk management. Neglect of some aspects
            of political economy is likely to have undermined prospects
            for the full and successful implementation of health reforms
            under the HSMP. The sequencing of reforms under the social
            assistance DPL and its follow-on implementation support is
            likely to have mitigated potential implementation setbacks
            associated with political feasibility, capacity, and fiscal
            constraints. The design and implementation of pilots to test
            and fine-tune reforms and the establishment of
            well-functioning management information system (MIS) and
            monitoring and evaluation (M and E) systems are critical to
            health and social assistance reform, as they can accommodate
            learning, provide evidence of the feasibility and benefits
            of such reform, and garner political support.

19761190.trustfund:
TF053326-PHRD-ALBANIA: HEALTH SYSTEM
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT,TF055804-PHRD-ALBANIA: HEALTH SYSTEM
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT-860458

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health System
            Modernization Project for Albania were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: the Program was able to
            achieve success because reforms spanned key areas of the
            health care system starting with the stewardship functions
            of the Ministry of Health (MOH) in health policy development
            and the Health Insurance Institute (HII) in health financing
            and provider payment reforms. The capacity of the Government
            to absorb technical assistance and implement complex
            institutional changes should be carefully evaluated to
            ensure knowledge transfer and a sustainable impact of the
            activities started under the Project. Close coordination and
            collaboration with United States Agency for International
            Development (USAID), World Health Organization (WHO), and
            Swiss Development Cooperation (SDC) in supporting
            implementation aspects of the program helped keep key
            activities on track and ensured complementarities of
            interventions. Since both the PIU and the Bank have no
            built-in capacity for the review of technical specifications
            and bid evaluation reports of medical equipment, the launch
            of procurement for medical equipment should allow more time
            in the procurement plan for the review of bidding documents
            and bid evaluation reports. Moreover, the bid validity
            period should also be for a longer period to avoid extension
            of bid validity period. The development and integration of
            health information systems in the health sector is complex.
            If a sector needs intervention in the implementation of a
            new information system, it is important that there is a
            specific team working on it right from the beginning of the
            Project, and adequate time, resources, and attention should
            be given on a priority basis. It will be important for the
            Bank to find a way to keep supporting the follow-up actions
            of the reforms introduced under the Project. Without a
            follow-on project, the Bank will not have leverage with the
            government regarding the reforms introduced.

16427875.trustfund:
TF053326-PHRD-ALBANIA: HEALTH SYSTEM
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT,TF055804-PHRD-ALBANIA: HEALTH SYSTEM
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT-860458

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Health System Modernization
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Health System
            Modernization Project for Albania are: (i) to improve the
            capacity of the Ministry of Health (MoH) and Health
            Insurance Institute (HII) to effectively formulate and
            implement health policies and reforms in provider payments,
            monitoring and quality assurance, (ii) to improve both the
            access to, and quality of, primary health care services,
            with an emphasis on those in poor and under-serviced areas,
            and (iii) to improve governance and management in the
            hospital sector. The extension is necessary to allow
            sufficient time for the delivery of the large medical
            equipment mentioned above. In November 2011 the Bank team
            carried out an implementation support mission of the Project
            and reached agreement with the Ministry of Health on the
            action plan for the implementation of the remaining project
            activities. This short extension will also ensure a
            successful completion of all project activities, including
            installation and testing of the purchased medical equipment.
            In addition, the extension of the Grant will ensure
            completion of the only remaining Technical Assistance (TA)
            activity, which supports the Health Insurance Institute in
            developing the secondary legislation for the Health
            Financing Law.

display_title.display_title:
Albania - Health System
            Modernization Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Health System Modernization
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of this Health System
            Modernization Project for Albania are: (i) to improve the
            capacity of the Ministry of Health (MoH) and Health
            Insurance Institute (HII) to effectively formulate and
            implement health policies and reforms in provider payments,
            monitoring and quality assurance, (ii) to improve both the
            access to, and quality of, primary health care services,
            with an emphasis on those in poor and under-serviced areas,
            and (iii) to improve governance and management in the
            hospital sector. The restructuring is a level two
            restructuring to make the following changes to the project
            being carried out by the Republic of Albania: (i) revision
            and cancellation of certain project activities, and (ii)
            reallocation of credit proceeds. This restructuring is
            expected to aid in the successful completion of all project
            activities before the project closing date.

15353785.trustfund:
TF053326-PHRD-ALBANIA: HEALTH SYSTEM
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT,TF055804-PHRD-ALBANIA: HEALTH SYSTEM
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT-860458

repnme.cdata!: Developing preventive health care in Albania

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            developing preventive health care in Albania. Each year,
            four hundred new cases of breast cancer were diagnosed in
            Albanian women. Most of them were discovered at a late
            stage, when the disease had advanced, was hard to treat, and
            often resulted in death. Health System Modernization Project
            supported by the World Bank, put four mammography machines
            in four big cities in different areas of Albania. The
            testing was free to all patients. A new campaign was
            launched urging health care practitioners to routinely
            screen women for breast cancer and to refer them for
            mammograms so that early diagnosis would both increase
            women's chances of living longer and reduce medical costs
